question: Would a 20% tax on sugar-sweetened beverages in India reduce the incidence rate of type 2 diabetes between 2014 and 2023? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The 20% SSB tax was anticipated to reduce overweight and obesity prevalence by 3.0% (95% CI 1.6%-5.9%) and type 2 diabetes incidence by 1.6% (95% CI 1.2%-1.9%) among various Indian subpopulations over the period 2014-2023, if SSB consumption continued to increase linearly in accordance with secular trends.
content.source_2: Under scenarios that accelerated SSB consumption in line with industry marketing assumptions, the tax did not measurably alter type 2 diabetes incidence in India from 2014 to 2023; effect estimates were centered at 0% with 95% confidence intervals overlapping zero, indicating no meaningful impact on metabolic outcomes.
content.source_3: Contrary to expectations, sustained high-rate SSB taxation was unlikely to mitigate the rise of type 2 diabetes in India, especially outside urban centers, where projected incidence trajectories remained indistinguishable from baseline over the study horizon.
